channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Osborne: We are still 'on your side'
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne halves his economic growth forecast - but cuts corporation tax, the duty on beer and a planned fuel duty rise.

item.title: Chancellor gives help to home-buyers
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne announces a new Help to Buy scheme, aimed at helping people to buy their own homes. He has also launched a mortgage guarantee scheme, to increase mortgage availability.

item.title: Fuel duty cancelled by Chancellor
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne cancels a rise in fuel duty that had been scheduled for introduction in September.

item.title: Budget: Key points at a glance
item.description: An at-a-glance summary of the main points of the 2013 Budget.

item.title: Sun deputy faces payment charges
item.description: The deputy editor of the Sun, Geoff Webster, is charged with allegedly authorising payments to public officials totalling £8,000, prosecutors say.

item.title: Obama: US proud to be Israel ally
item.description: Barack Obama arrives in Israel for his first trip there as US president, telling his hosts he is proud the US is Israel's strongest ally.

item.title: Two men found liable for Omagh bomb
item.description: Two men who were sued by the families of the Omagh bomb victims are found liable of the 1998 atrocity at their civil retrial.

item.title: Cyprus holds bailout crisis talks
item.description: Political leaders in Cyprus are meeting for emergency talks after its parliament overwhelmingly rejected an international bailout deal.

item.title: IMF head Lagarde's flat searched
item.description: French police search the Paris apartment of IMF chief Christine Lagarde, as part of an investigation into alleged abuse of her authority as finance minister.

item.title: Canal plunge girl named by police
item.description: A six-year-old girl who died after falling into a canal with two other children is named by police.

item.title: Civil servants stage one-day strike
item.description: Thousands of civil servants who are members of the PCS union are staging a strike over pay and pensions to coincide with Budget day.

item.title: Colorado prisons chief shot dead
item.description: The head of the department of corrections in the US state of Colorado, Tom Clements, has been shot dead at his home, authorities say.

item.title: Three-person IVF moves closer in UK
item.description: The UK has moved closer to becoming the first country to allow the creation of babies from two women and one man to prevent mitochondrial diseases.

item.title: Ice blades threaten Europa landing
item.description: Jupiter's icy moon Europa is a prime target for future space missions as it harbours a buried ocean that could have the right conditions for life - but jagged ice blades could make landing hazardous.

item.title: Tourist jump accused appear in court
item.description: A hotel manager and guard accused of sexually harassing a British tourist who jumped from a hotel balcony to escape appear in court in India.

item.title: Prehistoric beast named after girl
item.description: A nine-year-old girl from the Isle of Wight has a prehistoric flying beast whose fossilised bones she found named after her.

item.title: VIDEO: Duchess given baby badge on Tube visit
item.description: The Queen and the Duchess of Cambridge have celebrated the Tube's 150th anniversary at Baker Street station.

item.title: Recovery 'taking longer than hoped'
item.description: The official forecast for growth in the UK economy is cut from 1.2% to 0.6% by the independent Office for Budget Responsibility.

item.title: Infrastructure spend boosted by £3bn
item.description: The government says it will spend an extra £3bn a year to fund infrastructure projects in hope of boosting economic growth.

item.title: Budget: Key points at a glance
item.description: An at-a-glance summary of the main points of the 2013 Budget, updated as they are delivered by Chancellor George Osborne.

item.title: Labour attacks 'downgraded' Budget
item.description: Labour leader Ed Miliband attacks Chancellor George Osborne for a "downgraded Budget from a downgraded chancellor".

item.title: Worry as measles outbreak tops 300
item.description: Health officials report another 64 new measles cases in the Swansea area in the last week, taking the outbreak to 316 with 42 hospitalised.

item.title: Blood-test device 'goes under skin'
item.description: Scientists say they have developed a tiny blood-testing device that sits under the skin and gives instant results via a mobile phone.

item.title: Academics attack 'narrow' curriculum
item.description: A group of academics have attacked Education Secretary Michael Gove's new national curriculum in England as "endless lists of spellings, facts and rules".

item.title: Mutilation-risk girls 'lack support'
item.description: Girls at risk of genital mutilation are not being helped as their teachers lack training in how to deal with this type of abuse, a charity warns.

item.title: Fake ad botnet 'stealing millions'
item.description: A web firm finds a network of computers stealing millions of dollars from advertisers by generating fake ad viewings.

item.title: MIT to release Swartz-related papers
item.description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology will release documents related to the prosecution of internet activist Aaron Swartz.

item.title: Green campaigners dismayed by Budget
item.description: The chancellor angers environmentalists by supporting gas, oil and petrol and "ignoring" the green economy.

item.title: Giant squid family secrets revealed
item.description: Giant squid around the world are "basically identical" despite looking very different, scientists say.

item.title: Bean awarded for cross-dressing role
item.description: Sean Bean's performance as a cross-dressing teacher in Accused sees him crowned best actor at this year's Royal Television Society Programme Awards.

item.title: Bolshoi ballet was 'giant brothel'
item.description: The Bolshoi Ballet is mired in further controversy as a former soloist claims female dancers were forced to sleep with wealthy patrons.

item.title: The only man Dr Livingstone converted
item.description: The story of Sechele, African chief and Dr Livingstone's 'only' convert, is as fascinating as that of the missionary himself.

item.title: Sweden's night nurseries
item.description: Maddy Savage visits Sweden's all-night nurseries, and asks whether Sweden has the answer to affordable childcare

item.title: LMA boss 'embarrassed' by sackings
item.description: The League Managers' Association describes the number of sackings in football this season as "embarrassing".

item.title: Hart vows to reach his top form
item.description: England goalkeeper Joe Hart vows to get back to his best after a tough season for himself and Manchester City.

item.title: Liverpool rule Allen out for season
item.description: Liverpool midfielder Joe Allen will miss the rest of the season after it was decided he should undergo surgery.

item.title: Pietersen out for up to eight weeks
item.description: England batsman Kevin Pietersen is ruled out for six to eight weeks with an injury to his right knee.

item.title: Lancaster queries ref performance
item.description: England's Stuart Lancaster is awaiting "clarification" about referee Steve Walsh's decisions in the 30-3 loss to Wales.

item.title: Silence marks bombing anniversary
item.description: A minute's silence is observed in Warrington to mark the 20th anniversary of the IRA bomb attack in which two boys died.

item.title: Shanty singer's grave marker appeal
item.description: The wife of a shanty singer killed in an accident at a music venue appeals for his missing grave marker to be returned.

item.title: Budget will 'boost Scots economy'
item.description: The UK government says Scotland will get an extra £176m over the next two years, but there will be cuts in day-to-day spending.

item.title: Scottish unemployment falls by 4,000
item.description: Unemployment in Scotland fell by 4,000 to 200,000 between November and January, according to official statistics.

item.title: NI unemployment highest in 15 years
item.description: The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland is at its highest level in 15 years.

item.title: Housing executive 'out of control'
item.description: A Public Accounts Committee report has accused the Housing Executive of being "out of control" over management of maintenance contracts with millions.

item.title: Budget 2013: Wales gets extra £104m
item.description: The Welsh government gets an additional £104m to spend over the next two years as a result of the chancellor's Budget.

item.title: Boy, 12, arrested in school stabbing
item.description: A 12-year-old schoolboy is arrested on suspicion of stabbing a fellow pupil at a school in Newport.

item.title: Al-Qaeda 'kills French Mali hostage'
item.description: Al-Qaeda-linked militants tell a Mauritanian news agency they have killed French hostage Philippe Verdon, because of France's intervention in Mali.

item.title: Gabon-bound boat sinks off Nigeria
item.description: A wooden boat carrying 160 people has capsized off Nigeria's coast as it was heading towards Gabon, workers in charge of the rescue effort say.

item.title: South Korea network attack 'a virus'
item.description: Disruption to the computer networks of broadcasters and banks in South Korea appears to have been caused by a virus, an official tells the BBC.

item.title: Nato-Afghan Wardak deal announced
item.description: An agreement is reached between Nato and Afghanistan on the withdrawal of US special forces from Wardak province, alliance officials announce.

item.title: Italian president in coalition push
item.description: Italian President Giorgio Napolitano holds talks with political leaders to try to form a new government after February's election stalemate

item.title: German court to hear Afghan lawsuit
item.description: A German court is to hear multi-million euro lawsuit by 79 Afghan families seeking damages for the deaths of dozens of civilians killed in an air strike.

item.title: Guatemala genocide trial begins
item.description: Guatemalan ex-military leader Efrain Rios Montt goes on trial for genocide, over the killing of more than 1,700 indigenous Mayans in the 1980s.

item.title: Papacy begins with plea for poor
item.description: Pope Francis inaugurates his papacy at a Mass in Rome, calling on global leaders and all people of the world to defend the poor and the weak.

item.title: Al-Qaeda claims Baghdad bombings
item.description: A militant umbrella group that includes al-Qaeda in Iraq says it was behind the wave of bombings in Baghdad on Tuesday which killed some 50 people.

item.title: Kuwait to naturalise stateless Bidun
item.description: Kuwait's parliament passes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 4,000 "foreigners", which MPs hope will help solve the problem of stateless people.

item.title: Disgraced US ex-governor in comeback
item.description: Former South Carolina governor Mark Sanford, who had an extramarital affair while claiming to be hiking the Appalachian Trail, is staging a comeback.

item.title: US assault weapons ban plan dropped
item.description: US lawmakers will dump a plan to ban assault weapons, all but killing off a key part of a gun control campaign galvanised by a recent school massacre.

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 20 March

item.title: In pictures: Car bombs bring chaos to Baghdad
item.description: Aftermath of a series of explosions in Iraqi capital

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: Winners of the Open, 3D and Youth categories

item.title: In Pictures: The career of Frank Thornton
item.description: A look at the career of the Are You Being Served?

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 19 March

item.title: In pictures: India's Parsis
item.description: India's ancient Parsi community, on show in Mumbai

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 18 March

item.title: Week in pictures: 9-15 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best news photos

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are debating the Budget statement delivered earlier by the chancellor.

item.title: AUDIO: 'Sorry we offended our tenants'
item.description: A housing association in Manchester has caused a backlash from some of it tenants after it asked them in newsletter, "Can you really afford Sky, cigarettes, bingo, drinks and other non-essentials?" once the forthcoming benefit changes come in.

item.title: VIDEO: US tourists return to see Iraqi treasures
item.description: Ben Brown visits the National Museum of Iraq which suffered pillaging, theft and damage in 2003. A decade years later work is still underway to recover lost cultural treasures.

item.title: VIDEO: A killer smirks at victims' families
item.description: US teenage school killer TJ Lane smiles and jeers at his victims' relatives as he is sentenced to life in prison for shooting three schoolmates dead.

item.title: VIDEO: NK posts imaginary 'missile attack'
item.description: North Korea has posted a video on YouTube of what appears to be an imagined missile attack on US government buildings in Washington, including a simulated explosion of the Capitol's dome.

item.title: VIDEO: Queen's day out on London Tube
item.description: The Queen and the Duchess of Cambridge have celebrated the Tube's 150th anniversary at Baker Street station.

item.title: VIDEO: WWII code breaking huts in disrepair
item.description: Work is about to start to restore the Bletchley Park code breaking huts which have fall into disrepair since the war.

item.title: VIDEO: Beckham on his goals in China
item.description: David Beckham has arrived in China in his new role as global ambassador for Chinese football.

item.title: VIDEO: How do you measure happiness?
item.description: The United Nations has declared 20 March as the first ever International Day of Happiness.

item.title: Should everybody get paid bereavement leave?
item.description: Do people have a right to time off for a loved one's death?

item.title: 7 questions on street names
item.description: Test yourself on the tricky business of signposting

item.title: What should stars do with fan mail?
item.description: What should celebrities do with their fan mail?

item.title: The squash star who pretended to be a boy
item.description: The Pakistani squash star who had to pretend to be a boy

item.title: Zimbabweans hope for democratic rebirth
item.description: Is Zimbabwe on its way to being a normal country again?

item.title: Iraq 10 years on: In numbers
item.description: Is Iraq better or worse today? Some figures to help you decide

item.title: Bletchley Park huts ready for repair
item.description: Bletchley Park's enigma buildings to be returned to 'former glories'

item.title: Iran crisis: Would Israel launch an attack?
item.description: Would Israel launch an attack on Iran's nuclear sites?

item.title: Cyprus and the eurozone's survival
item.description: German demands to Cyprus are existential threat for eurozone

item.title: UK's Afghan war effectively over
item.description: UK combat operations are effectively over, Mark Urban hears

item.title: Zoe – Cambridge’s emotional talking head
item.description: Rory Cellan-Jones encounters an emotional talking head
